reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s main optimistic pathway beyond WAM-convergence—partial AM-convergence plus moral trade—by claiming extortion/threats will usually overwhelm gains-from-trade. That’s moderately central because it undercuts a key source of optimism, but it doesn’t fully overturn the paper’s broader conclusion, which already flags threats as potentially value-destroying and treats trade as conditional on preventing them. The critique adds a plausible amplification (cheap creation of bad states, commitment tech, spite/status preferences) but provides little detailed support (no equilibrium analysis, no comparison to plausible threat-prevention institutions), so it only modestly strengthens the paper’s own worry rather than decisively refuting the trade path. Most claims are directionally plausible, but the ‘likely dominates’/‘equilibrium closer to hostage-taking’ parts are speculative. It’s clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: "Threats and extortion undermine the value-generating trade route"
